Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = -\\lambda u\\), where \\(\\lambda > 0\\) is a constant. We study the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to the function \\( u(x, t) \\) versus simply evolving \\( u(x, t) \\) over time.

If the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x, 0)) \\) is applied to an initial function \\( u(x, 0) \\) and the result is then evolved subject to \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = -\\lambda u\\) without further intervention, will the solution \\( u(x, t) \\) at time t be the same as directly evolving \\( u(x, 0) \\) under the given partial differential equation?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform changes the problem space from the spatial domain to the frequency domain, where the governing equation transforms differently due to properties of the Fourier transform on differential operators. Direct evolution and evolution post-transformation are not equivalent processes in this context.
